anchors: U.S. Constitution (Supremacy Clause, Ninth, Tenth, Fourth, Fourteenth)
49 U.S.C. Subtitle VI (Motor Vehicle and Driver Programs)
49 CFR Part 40 (ODAPC drug/alcohol testing — safety-sensitive employees)

dot_testing_scope.description: 49 CFR Part 40 applies only to DOT-regulated, safety-sensitive employees with an employment relationship to a covered employer.

federal_sources: No general federal requirement that private citizens obtain a commercial-style license to exercise ordinary movement.
driver_licensing.notes: States may not transform private movement into commercial conduct purely to extend FMCSR-like control.

federal_sources: No federal statute converts use of public roads into consent for chemical testing of non-commercial drivers.
49 CFR Part 40 is limited to safety-sensitive employees.
implied_consent.notes: Implied consent doctrines applied to non-commercial drivers are structurally suspect under the Fourth, Fifth, Ninth, and Fourteenth Amendments.

commercial_transport.notes: Here, the core question is whether the facts match the commercial definitions in Title 49 and FMCSRs.

fmcsr_adoption.notes: States must adopt FMCSRs for commercial motor carriers, not for ordinary non-commercial drivers.

vehicle_registration.notes: Registration regimes still must respect constitutional structure but generally do not invoke FMCSR directly.

insurance.notes: Insurance requirements are typically state-law based but cannot be used as an excuse to import FMCSR into private movement.

federal_sources: Congress ties some highway funds to impaired driving enforcement, but does not expand FMCSR jurisdiction to all private motorists.
dwi_dui_owi.notes: Impaired driving laws must still comply with Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment constraints.

void_ab_initio_conditions: Contradicts explicit constitutional text or structure.
Removes or nullifies an existing remedy for rights violations.
Creates a penalty for exercising a retained right.
Invents power not delegated to any level of government.
Transforms private, non-commercial conduct into commercial conduct without textual authority.

driver_licensing_private: Fourth Amendment (when used to justify stops/arrests)
